snippet.title: Scott in the mix after WGC round one
snippet.content: ADAM Scott has battled to keep his place among the leaderboard after the first round of the World Golf Championships-Bridgestone Invitational in Ohio. The Australian world No.17 dropped four shots on the back nine but managed to bag six birdies to extract a two-under-par 68 at Firestone Country Club. It left Scott, the 2011 WGC-Bridgestone champion, just three shots back of the lead. Belgian young gun Thomas Pieters set the pace with a 65 to climb to five-under and he will take a one-shot lead into day two over Scotland's Russell Knox (66). Sharing third place at three-under are big guns Jordan Spieth, Rory McIlroy, Jon Rahm and Bubba Watson as well as Kevin Kisner and Ross Fisher (all 67). The 37-year-old Scott shares ninth place and is the leading Australian, with countryman Scott Hend (70) next best at even-par in a tie for 22nd. World No.7 Jason Day limped to a 71 to shared 33rd, while fellow Australians Rod Pampling and Marc Leishman are tied for 53rd after the pair signed for 73. Sam Brazel rounded out the Australian contingent with a 74 dropping him to 62nd. The WGC-Bridgestone is a 76-man event with no 36-hole cut featuring the world's top 50 golfers and US PGA Tour winners from this season.
